title: Lanchester Valley Walk Route

images.title: Gordon Griffiths / Lanchester Valley Walk
images.caption: The Walk passes under Broom Lane next to the railway.

images.title: Mick Garratt / Lanchester Valley Walk
images.caption: Lanchester Valley Walk - view of the surfaced tree lined path approaching Langley. Incorporating National Cycleway No. 14 and follows the route of a disused railway. The "Walking to Health" signs are a local initiative and erected every 500m.

images.title: Oliver Dixon / Lanchester Valley Path at Baxter Wood
images.caption: Path at Baxter Wood. The Network milepost is of the "Welsh" design.

images.title: Mick Garratt / Disused Railway Bridge, Lanchester Valley Walk
images.caption: Disused Railway Bridge. The grid line passes diagonally through the bridge which seems to have been built purely for farming purposes.

images.title: Mick Garratt / Public Bridleway, Hurbuck Cottages
images.caption: Public Bridleway, Hurbuck Cottages

images.title: Mick Garratt / Disused Railway Bridge over the River Browney
images.caption: Disused Railway Bridge over the River Browney

description: This shared cycling and walking path uses the route of the railway originally built to carry iron ore to Consett Steelworks. The path runs from Durham to Consett passing Bearpark, Langley Park and Lanchester. Route highlights include the 13th century Beaurepaire Priory at Bearpark, Lanchester Roman Fort and some lovely views of the River Browney. It's a fairly flat path which runs for about 12 miles. The Brandon - Bishop Auckland Walk and the Deerness Valley Way run close to the trail. They also run along disused railway lines and are a great way to further explore the area.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: At Consett the route links up with three other rail trails where you can extend your walking and cycling. These include the Consett and Sunderland Railway Path, the Waskerley Way and the Derwent Valley Walk. On the edge of the town there's also Allensford Country Park to explore. There's nice riverside trails, a decent cafe and a lovely waterfall on the Wharnley Burn in this popular and picturesque park. For more walking ideas in the area see the County Durham Walks page.

display_address: Lanchester Valley Walk, Relly Farm, Brandon and Byshottles, Durham, County Durham, North East, England, DH7 7RJ, United Kingdom
